abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Urban Development Project in
            Burundi. The main objectives of the project were: (i) in the
            short term, to strengthen the economies of secondary towns
            and, through urban-rural linkages, the economy of their
            hinterland; and (ii) in the long term, to assist the
            Borrower's urban growth by improving living conditions
            of the urban populations in the municipality of Bujumbura,
            and the communes of Gitega, Ngozi, Kayanza, Rumonge and
            Bururi. The project merits a rating of Satisfactory as do
            the Bank's and the Borrower's performances. The
            project's physical objectives were substantially
            achieved. Private sector development objectives were
            partially reached. Sector policy, institutional development
            and public sector management objectives, were partially
            attained. The following lessons can be learned from the
            Second Urban Development Project: (a) No matter how well
            prepared and implemented a project is, its development
            impact may be jeopardized in a situation of continued
            political instability and civil disturbance. (b) To
            facilitate implementation and supervision, it is advisable
            to avoid overly ambitious and complex urban development
            projects with a mix of components and unrelated activities.
            (c) In an under-urbanized country like Burundi, urban policy
            and urban development projects must focus particularly on
            administrative and fiscal institution building. (d) To
            achieve a sustained urban development, institutional
            building and Government strong commitment to this task are
            crucial and needed at early stages of project
            implementation. (e) Responsibilities of all parties must be
            well defined and clearly understood before project
            implementation to avoid a situation in which project units
            have to carry out inappropriate tasks as a last resort.
